{{Infobox military unit | unit_name=2 Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group Signal Squadron | image=[[File:2 Sig Sqn Logo.jpg|100px]] | caption= | dates=1995 - Present | country={{flag|Canada}} | allegiance= | branch=[[Communications and Electronics Branch]] | type= | role=To empower Commander 2 CMBG and his staff by providing the communication services necessary to exercise command and control (C2) over the formation. | garrison=[[Garrison Petawawa]] | garrison_label= | nickname= | patron= | motto=''Velox, Versutus, Vigilans'' (Speed, Accuracy, Vigiliance) | colors=French grey and dark blue | colors_label= | march=[[The Mercury March]] | mascot=Jimmy | equipment= | equipment_label= | battles= | anniversaries=24 June 1995 | decorations= | battle_honours= | commander1=Major Michael Janelle | commander1_label=Commanding Officer | commander2=Chief Warrant Officer Michelle Harris | commander2_label=Regimental Sergeant Major | commander3= | commander3_label= | notable_commanders= | identification_symbol_2= | identification_symbol_2_label= | identification_symbol_4= | identification_symbol_4_label= }} '''2 Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group Headquarters & Signal Squadron''' (2 CMBG HQ & Sig Sqn) is a Regular Force Army unit of the [[Canadian Forces]] garrisoned at [[CFB Petawawa|Canadian Forces Base (CFB) Petawawa]]. The unit's parent formation is [[2 Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group]] (2 CMBG). The squadron was housed in eight separate buildings but consolidated into one in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.army.forces.gc.ca/land-terre/news-nouvelles/transcription-eng.asp?id=4494 |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=Signal squadron to move under one roof}}</ref>
== History == The [[Special Service Force]] Headquarters and Signal Squadron (SSF HQ & Sig Sqn) was renamed 2 Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group Headquarters and Signal Squadron on 1 June 1995, coincident with the name change of its parent formation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rcsigs.ca/ViewUnit/7/ |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=2 CMBG HQ and Sigs}}</ref> The squadron has provided personnel and equipment for many [[United Nations]] (UN) and [[North Atlantic Treaty Organization]] (NATO) missions, particularly [[IFOR|Operation ALLIANCE]] (Former Yugoslavia) in 1996, [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1201|Operation PRUDENCE]] (Central African Republic) in 1998 and [[Kosovo Force|Operation KINETIC]] (Kosovo) in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comfec-cefcom.forces.gc.ca/pa-ap/ops/pastops-eng.asp |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=Past Operations}}</ref> The squadron has been involved with significant domestic operations including the [[1997 Red River Flood|Winnipeg flood]] in 1997, the [[North American ice storm of 1998|ice storms]] in 1998, and the [[36th G8 summit|G8 Summit in Huntsville]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cg.cfpsa.ca/cg-pc/Petawawa/EN/InformationandFAQ/Publications/Documents/greenbook2011.pdf |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=Canadian Forces Base Petawawa Directory and City Guide 2010-2011}}</ref>
==Afghanistan==
=== Kabul (2003-2005) === In July 2003, the squadron deployed to [[Afghanistan]] as part of [[Operation ATHENA]] Rotation 0 with a transfer of command authority on 17 July 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cefcom.forces.gc.ca/pa-ap/ops/jtfafg-foiafg/tl03-eng.asp |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=The international campaign against terrorism : A timeline of Canadian Forces participation}}</ref> Under the command of Major Sean Sullivan, the unit provided integral communications support to the Canadian-led Kabul Multi-National Brigade (KMNB) led by [[Peter Devlin|Brigadier-General Peter Devlin]], then Commander [[2 CMBG]]. Although the core of the squadron was stationed within [[Camp Warehouse]], the squadron had several outstations in allied locations throughout KMNB including [[Kabul International Airport]] and radio rebroadcast site on TV Tower Hill. They returned to [[CFB Petawawa]] in January 2004. The remainder of the time in Kabul prior to the move to Kandahar in 2005,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20050629/soldiers_kandahar_050629/ |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=Canadian soldiers begin deploying to Kandahar}}</ref> 2 CMBG HQ & Sig Sqn only provided individual augmentation to the subsequent rotations.
=== Kandahar (2006-2011) === The G6 (Communications - [[General Staff System]]) Staff for the National Command Element of Rotation 2 (Task Force 3-06) was composed of the leadership of 2 CMBG HQ & Sig Sqn. This period saw some of the heaviest fighting during the Afghanistan Campaign including [[Operation Medusa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legionmagazine.com/en/index.php/2007/09/operation-medusa-the-battle-for-panjwai/ |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=Operation Medusa: The Battle For Panjwai}}</ref> A complete squadron again deployed in May 2008 as [[Task Force Kandahar]] Signal Squadron under the leadership of Major (promoted Lieutenant-Colonel on tour) James Lambert as part of Task Force 5-08 (also called Rotation 5.5). When Brigadier-General Denis Thompson passed command of [[Task Force Kandahar]] to his successor, Brigadier-General Jonathan Vance on 19 February 2009, the squadron redeployed to Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cefcom.forces.gc.ca/pa-ap/fs-ev/2009/02/19-eng.asp |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=A rotation in review: BGen Denis Thompson reflects on tour's successes}}</ref> The squadron deployed to Kandahar once again in August 2010 under Lieutenant-Colonel Chris McGuffin to support the last Task Force Headquarters (Task Force 5-10) under the combat-operations mandate. The squadron handed over to the Mission Transition Task Force in July 2011.
===Fallen soldiers=== During the Afghanistan campaign, the squadron lost two soldiers killed in action: * Corporal Matthew McCully of Orangeville Ontario, was killed on 25 May 2007 when he stepped on a land mine while on foot patrol.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orangeville.org/news_detail.php?id=900 |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=Military funeral planned for Cpl. Matthew McCully}}</ref> * Corporal Kenneth O'Quinn was killed on 3 March 2009 when the vehicle he was in detonated an improvised explosive device (IED).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/story/2009/03/05/oquinn-nb.html |accessdate=2011-03-17 |title=N.B. town mourns soldier's death | work=CBC News|date=2009-03-05}}</ref>
